title: How to Record a CD to an Audio Cassette Using Amplifier

steps.title: Set up your Amplifier and required equipment in one place.
steps.content: Set up your Amplifier and required equipment in one place. Make sure you have access to the back of the amplifier and other equipment.

steps.title: Plug in the amplifier to the wall outlet or power strip (multiple outlets).
steps.content: Plug in the amplifier to the wall outlet or power strip (multiple outlets). This works best if you use an amplifier with 2-prong or 3-prong power inputs so that you won't need so many ports in your wall-outlet.

steps.title: Connect your CD/DVD player to your cassette deck (recorder).
steps.content: Connect your CD/DVD player to your cassette deck (recorder). Connect "Audio Out" on the CD/DVD player INTO the "Line IN" on the cassette recorder, using RCA jacks. If red is present but no white, use the red in the red ports and the other color (sometimes black) in the other port. Connect the same colors on BOTH devices.

steps.title: Locate "Line Out" on the tape recorder/player.
steps.content: Locate "Line Out" on the tape recorder/player.

steps.title: Plug in the correct colors, and then feed the unconnected RCA ends into the corresponding "Tape 1" or "Tape 2" inputs on the amplifier.
steps.content: Plug in the correct colors, and then feed the unconnected RCA ends into the corresponding "Tape 1" or "Tape 2" inputs on the amplifier.

steps.title: Remember:
steps.content: Remember: Red into Red and the other color into where the 'white' RCA jack would normally go.)

steps.title: The CD/DVD player setup:
steps.content: The CD/DVD player setup: Turn on DVD/CD player. Insert disc you want to copy from. Close player and press the "Stop" button on the player (or on remote if available).

steps.title: The Cassette Tape recorder set-up:
steps.content: The Cassette Tape recorder set-up: Open recording deck (the side where recording can take place, usually the right side deck). Insert blank tape or old tape that you want to record over. (No longer than 90 minutes due to magnetic strips being too thin and wearing out easily during playback).

steps.title: This can be done two ways:
steps.content: This can be done two ways: Turn on amplifier and set it to Tape Deck 1 or 2 (whichever you plugged the RCA jacks into). First Method:Second Method: Press the record and play buttons simultaneously (ie. "at the same time") on the Audiotape player and press the play button on the CD/DVD player after about 3 seconds of the Audiotape recording. Press play on the DVD/CD player AND at the same time press the Record/play buttons on the cassette deck. Note: This method may cause your tape to not catch the beginning of a song or speaking part from the CD you're copying from.

steps.title: When the CD is done playing, you can hit the stop button on the recorder and stop the CD from playing.
steps.content: When the CD is done playing, you can hit the stop button on the recorder and stop the CD from playing. Put disk away and write down a title on the tape you copied to. Insert new disk and continue recording on the tape if you have free space. To record again, simply press record on the deck and the play button on the DVD/CD player as described in the previous step. Don't forget to turn everything off and unplug your equipment when you're finished!
